newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Luxembourg denies it is a money laundering centre.
newsitem.headline: Luxembourg denies it is a money laundering centre.

text.p: The Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, the tiny banking centre and tax haven for neighbouring countries, denied on Thursday that it is the home of money launderers.
"Luxembourg money laundering legislation is one of the strictest in Europe, and is set to become even stricter," the Luxembourg Justice and Foreign Ministries said in a statement.
It said the statement was in reaction to Belgian press reports about money laundering in Luxembourg.
Earlier this month, Belgian newsletter Faxtuel said that foreign leaders, political parties and private individuals were laundering money through Luxembourg bank accounts.
It said the accounts belonged among others to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi and Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko.
"The Faxtuel report relates no precise facts...it makes a mixture of idle chatter," the Luxembourg statement said.
Belgian authorities are currently investigating the report, which was based on a note from an assistant to Belgium's former ambassador in Luxembourg.

A spokesman for Belgian Justice Minister Stefaan De Clerck said earlier this month that several investigations were already under way into possible money laundering and tax evasion schemes in Luxembourg by Belgian political parties and nationals.
"This organised leak of the embassy report is part of a systematic slander campaign against the Luxembourg financial market," the Luxembourg statement said.
And in unusally sharp fashion it added: "Instead of accusing without rhyme or reason the Luxembourg financial market and its legal system, some people better clean up their own act."
The issue of banking and fiscal legislation is very touchy in the Grand Duchy, whose tight banking secrecy laws have spawned a thriving banking industry.
Tiny Luxembourg -- population just 413,000 -- has long blocked EU efforts to harmonise fiscal legislation in the European Union.
It will hold the rotating EU presidency in the second half of this year.
